questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is given below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E. Histolytica

 

  • The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir.
  • The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer.
  • The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces.
  • Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.
  • The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.
  • The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, has a simple life cycle that involves ingestion of eggs, hatching in the intestine, and laying eggs around the anus. It does not form trophozoites or cysts.

 

Option B. A. duodenal: Ancylostoma duodenale, a hookworm, has a life cycle involving skin penetration by larvae, migration through the bloodstream to the lungs, ascent to the throat, and finally ingestion to the intestine where they mature. It does not have cysts or trophozoites.

 

Option C. B. coli: Balantidium coli is a ciliate protozoan with a life cycle that involves a cyst stage and a trophozoite stage, similar to E. histolytica. However, it is characterized by the presence of cilia and typically associated with pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective

 

The life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica includes the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst stages, with transmission primarily by the fecal-oral route. The most frequent site of systemic disease caused by E. histolytica is the liver.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of feeling tired, dry skin, and recent weight gain despite no changes in her diet. She also notes experiencing constipation and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is enlarged but non-tender, and her reflexes are slow. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated TSH level and low free T4. An ultrasound of the thyroid shows a diffusely enlarged gland with heterogeneous echotexture. A biopsy of the thyroid is performed, and the histology is shown. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

Explanation:

 

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder and the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. The condition is characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, constipation, and increased sensitivity to cold, which are all signs of hypothyroidism. The physical exam typically reveals an enlarged thyroid gland, which may feel firm but is usually non-tender. The ultrasound findings of a diffusely enlarged thyroid with heterogeneous texture further support the diagnosis. Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis shows lymphocytic infiltration, germinal center formation, and Hurthle cell changes.

 

Pathophysiology: In Hashimoto thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and gradual thyroid destruction. This autoimmune process is mediated by autoantibodies against thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin, resulting in a gradual decline in thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subacute thyroiditis: This option is incorrect because subacute thyroiditis, often following a viral illness, typically presents with a painful, tender thyroid gland. Patients may initially experience hyperthyroidism due to thyroid inflammation and release of stored hormones, followed by a period of hypothyroidism. Histology would show granulomatous inflammation, not the lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Riedel thyroiditis: This option is incorrect because Riedel thyroiditis is a rare condition characterized by fibrous replacement of thyroid tissue, leading to a hard, fixed thyroid mass. Symptoms are typically more mechanical, such as compression of surrounding structures, and histology shows dense fibrosis without the characteristic lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

 

Option D. Toxic multinodular goiter: This option is incorrect as toxic multinodular goiter usually presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Ultrasound would show a nodular thyroid, and histology would demonstrate nodules of varying sizes rather than diffuse lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder and the leading cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions. It presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, an enlarged thyroid, and characteristic histological findings of lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells. Proper recognition of clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings is essential for diagnosis and management

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

 

Warburg metabolism is used by neoplastic cells to generate metabolic intermediates required for cell growth and multiplication.

 

Even when there is plenty of oxygen available, cancer cells shift their glucose metabolism away from the oxygen-hungry but efficient mitochondria and towards glycolysis. This phenomenon is known as the Warburg effect, and it is also referred to as aerobic glycolysis.

 

This metabolic change is so common in tumors that some consider it the eighth cancer hallmark.

 

Even though the latter produces more ATP, cancer cells prefer glycolysis (2 ATP) to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism. It's because pure oxidative phosphorylation generates a lot of ATP while also converting glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties to use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

 

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells: Incorrect. The Warburg effect actually increases glucose uptake and utilization by cancer cells to meet their high metabolic demands.

 

Option C. It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production: Incorrect. Glycolysis produces less ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation. The advantage of the Warburg effect lies in providing metabolic intermediates, not in ATP production.

 

Option D. It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal: Incorrect. While cancer cells do evade apoptosis and become immortal, this is not the direct reason they utilize the Warburg effect. The Warburg effect primarily supports cell growth and multiplication through the generation of biosynthetic precursors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neoplastic cells utilize the Warburg metabolism to generate metabolic intermediates necessary for cell growth and multiplication. Despite being less efficient in ATP production, glycolysis provides carbon moieties needed for biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, supporting rapid proliferation and cellular maintenance.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen’s chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adolescents

 

Explanation

 

The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents. The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:

 

  1. Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  2. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  3. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  4. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  5. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  6. Suicide/Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.

 

Now Extended to become – HEEADSS

 

E – Eating and Exercise

 

S - Safety

 

Educational objective: 

 

The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Support and education

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks.

 

The primary management for postpartum blues is support and education about the condition, emphasizing its transient nature and differentiating it from the more severe postpartum depression.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Useful in postpartum depression but not needed for the milder blues.

 

Option B. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for postpartum depression but is not the primary treatment for transient postpartum blues.

 

Option C. Lithium carbonate: Not indicated for postpartum blues or depression; used mainly for bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Mark the correct instrument shown in the image ?(Aiims Nov 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic port trocar

 

Explanation

 

The laparoscopic port trocar is used to create a pneumoperitoneum and insert instruments during laparoscopic procedures. It allows access to the peritoneal cavity and maintains the pneumoperitoneum when instruments are exchanged. The diagram shows the trocar handle, shaft, shield, and cannula, which are characteristic components of the laparoscopic port trocar.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Peritoneal dialysis catheter: This catheter is used for peritoneal dialysis, not for creating pneumoperitoneum or inserting instruments during laparoscopic surgery.

 

Option C. Endoscopic ultrasound probe: This probe is used for endoscopic ultrasound procedures, not for laparoscopic surgery.

 

Option D. Dpl catheter: A diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) catheter is used for diagnostic lavage in trauma, not for laparoscopic procedures.

 

Educational Objectives :The laparoscopic port trocar is essential for creating pneumoperitoneum and allowing the insertion and exchange of instruments during laparoscopic surgeries

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painless, progressively enlarging mass in his right testicle, noticed over the past six months. He denies any history of trauma, infection, or systemic symptoms. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender testicular mass is palpated, which does not transilluminate. Tumor markers, including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), are within normal limits. Scrotal ultrasound reveals a solid, hypoechoic lesion within the testis. An orchidectomy is performed, and histopathological analysis of the specimen is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminoma

 

Explanation:

 

Seminomas are the most common type of testicular germ cell tumors in adult men, often presenting as painless, firm testicular masses. Morphologically, seminomas are well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, and homogeneous masses with a fleshy and lobulated cut surface, typically without hemorrhage or necrosis. Histologically, they consist of sheets of large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders. The nuclei are centrally located, large, and round with prominent nucleoli. Minimal mitotic activity and a lack of significant inflammatory infiltrate, such as lymphocytes or syncytiotrophoblast cells, are typical features, which help distinguish seminomas from more aggressive germ cell tumors.

 

 

Pathophysiology: Seminomas arise from germ cells and exhibit relatively indolent growth compared to other testicular tumors. Their uniform histological appearance and response to radiation and chemotherapy contribute to an excellent prognosis when detected early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Embryonal carcinoma: This option is incorrect because embryonal carcinoma is a more aggressive, poorly differentiated germ cell tumor often associated with elevated tumor markers such as AFP or β-hCG. Histologically, it displays a more disorganized architecture with high mitotic activity, pleomorphic cells, and areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, contrasting with the orderly appearance of seminomas.

 

Option C. Spermatocytic tumor: This option is incorrect as spermatocytic tumors are rare testicular tumors typically occurring in older men. They have a different histological appearance characterized by a mix of small, medium, and large cells without the clear cytoplasm seen in seminomas. They are generally slow-growing and do not show the same aggressive behavior as seminomas.

 

Option D. Testicular lymphoma: This option is incorrect because testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in older men but is very rare in younger adults. It usually presents with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma histology, showing sheets of lymphoid cells rather than the large, clear cells characteristic of seminomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminomas are the most common testicular germ cell tumors in men, presenting as painless masses with characteristic histological features of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and minimal inflammatory infiltrates. Recognizing the typical morphological and histological features of seminomas aids in accurate diagnosis and management, contributing to a favorable prognosis with appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing

 

  • RNA editing is not a synthesis process; it involves modification of the pre-existing RNA sequence after transcription.
  • It may include: Base substitution (e.g., A-to-I, C-to-U)
  • Directionality (5′ to 3′) does not apply to these post-transcriptional modifications in the same way it applies to polymerization.
  • An example of RNA editing is apoB gene and mRNA
     

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where RNA polymerase synthesizes RNA from a DNA template.

 

Option B. DNA Replication: Occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, with DNA polymerase adding nucleotides to the growing DNA strand.

 

Option C. DNA Repair: DNA repair processes, including nucleotide excision repair and base excision repair, involve synthesis in the 5' to 3' direction during the filling in of repaired regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair.

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Fr with respect to size of Foley's catheter refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outer Diameter

 

Fr, short for French, is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter. It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings. The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter. For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.

 

Therefore, the diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abortion: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.

 

Option C. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents due to a painless swelling on the right side of her neck that has gradually increased in size over the past six months. The swelling is firm, non-tender, and located laterally without transillumination. On further examination, the child has several hyperpigmented macules and freckling noted in the axillary and inguinal regions. She has no history of trauma, fever, or significant weight loss. Based on her clinical presentation and examination findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neural tumor

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's presentation suggests a neural tumor, specifically a neurofibroma, which is commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Key characteristics include a painless lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient, the non-tender nature of the mass, and the presence of café-au-lait spots and freckling in axillary and inguinal regions. Neurofibromas are benign nerve sheath tumors that appear as firm, rubbery masses and are often associated with NF1, a genetic condition marked by multiple neural tumors, café-au-lait macules, and axillary/inguinal freckling.

 

Clinical Characteristics:

 

  1. Presence of a painless, lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient.
  2. The mass is firm and non-tender.
  3. Associated with skin manifestations such as freckles and hyperpigmented patches (café-au-lait spots), often seen in NF1.

 

Pathophysiology: Neurofibromas in NF1 arise due to mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which leads to a loss of function of neurofibromin, a tumor suppressor protein. This results in uncontrolled cell growth, leading to the formation of neurofibromas and other characteristic lesions of NF1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoblastoma: This option is incorrect because lipoblastomas are benign soft tissue tumors derived from embryonic fat, commonly presenting as soft, lobulated masses. They lack the firm texture and neural association seen in neurofibromas and are not linked to café-au-lait spots or characteristic freckling.

 

Option C. Branchial cleft cyst: This option is incorrect as branchial cleft cysts are congenital neck masses that are soft, fluctuant, and often become infected, presenting with pain and drainage. They are not associated with systemic findings such as freckles or café-au-lait spots and lack the typical features of neural tumors.

 

Option D. Reactive lymphadenopathy: This option is incorrect because reactive lymphadenopathy typically presents as tender, mobile lymph nodes often associated with recent infections. It is not characterized by persistent, firm, painless masses or associated skin findings seen in NF1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural tumors, particularly neurofibromas, are commonly seen in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder presenting with painless, firm masses and associated skin findings such as café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. Early recognition of these features is essential for diagnosing NF1 and managing the potential complications associated with neural tumors

questions.text: Transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation is used to reduce pain. What is the mechanism behind this?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central inhibition: Incorrect. Central inhibition is not the primary mechanism of action for TENS in pain relief.

 

Option B. Desensitization: Incorrect. Desensitization refers to a reduction in response to a stimulus over time, which is not the primary mechanism for TENS.

 

Option D. Descending inhibition: Incorrect. While descending inhibitory pathways are involved in the modulation of pain, the gate control theory specifically explains the mechanism behind TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) reduces pain through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large diameter afferent fibers.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with bleeding per rectum and was diagnosed with carcinoma of the colon. The patient underwent an extended right hemicolectomy. Identify the instrument being used by the surgeon in the image below: (AIIMS Nov 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monopolar cautery

 

Explanation

 

The instrument being used by the surgeon is monopolar cautery. Monopolar electrocautery is employed for cutting, blending, desiccation, and fulguration during surgery. It uses a pencil instrument where the active electrode is placed at the entry site to cut tissue and coagulate bleeding. This device is versatile and effective, making it a common choice in surgical procedures.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. LigaSure vessel ligating system: LigaSure is an electrothermal bipolar tissue sealing system used primarily in laparoscopic surgeries. It improves vessel sealing with minimal lateral thermal spread but is not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Harmonic scalpel: This instrument uses ultrasonic vibrations to cut and coagulate tissue simultaneously, different from the electrocautery mechanism.

 

Option D. Hyfrecator: This is a type of electrosurgical unit used for coagulation, typically in dermatological procedures, and is not suited for the described surgical scenario.

 

Educational Objectives :Monopolar electrocautery is widely used in various surgical procedures for its versatility and effectiveness in cutting and coagulating tissue

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coiling

 

The management of choice for aneurysms by interventional radiologists is coiling. This minimally invasive procedure involves the insertion of platinum coils into the aneurysm through an endovascular route. The coils promote clotting within the aneurysm, effectively reducing the risk of rupture and stabilizing the aneurysm.

 

Coiling is performed under the guidance of digital subtraction angiography (DSA), which allows the radiologist to visualize the blood vessels and accurately place the coils within the aneurysm. This technique has become the gold standard for treating cerebral aneurysms due to its minimally invasive nature and high success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clipping: This is a surgical procedure where a neurosurgeon places a clip at the neck of the aneurysm to prevent blood flow into it. While effective, it is more invasive than coiling and typically not performed by interventional radiologists.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). It is not a treatment for aneurysms but a supportive therapy to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Angioplasty: Angioplasty is used to widen narrowed or obstructed blood vessels, often in cases of peripheral arterial disease. It is not a primary treatment for aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coiling is the preferred management for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists, involving the insertion of coils to promote clotting and stabilize the aneurysm.

questions.text: A 3-year-old toxic child presents with tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and developed difficulty in swallowing with drooling of saliva within 4-6 hours of fever. Along with airway management. Which of the following needs to be given? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Ceftriaxone

 

The clinical presentation of this 3-year-old child, including tachypnea, high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, dysphagia, and drooling of saliva, suggests acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Acute epiglottitis is an emergency that can result in airway obstruction due to severe inflammation of the epiglottis and surrounding structures. The management of acute epiglottitis involves the following key steps:

 

  1. Airway Management: Immediate attention to securing the airway is crucial, often requiring endotracheal intubation or, in severe cases, tracheostomy, to prevent airway obstruction.
  2. Empirical Antibiotic Therapy: IV Ceftriaxone is the antibiotic of choice for empirical treatment in acute epiglottitis. Ceftriaxone covers the most common causative organisms, including Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), which is the most frequent pathogen responsible for this condition.
  3. Dexamethasone is often used as adjunctive therapy to reduce airway edema.

 

Once the culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotic therapy may be adjusted according to the identified pathogen. The immediate empirical use of Ceftriaxone is crucial in managing this condition until further microbiological data is obtained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline: This treatment is typically indicated in cases of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not in acute epiglottitis. Croup presents with a "barking" cough and usually a more gradual onset compared to epiglottitis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria antitoxin: This is used in the treatment of diphtheria, which presents with a characteristic thick gray pseudomembrane in the throat, and is not related to the clinical features described here. Diphtheria can also cause descending paralysis and other systemic symptoms not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Start steroids: Steroids are indicated in the management of croup to reduce airway inflammation but are not the first-line treatment in epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency requiring immediate airway management and empirical antibiotic therapy, with IV Ceftriaxone being the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not performed via the perineal approach in a patient with rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein operation

 

This procedure is designed to treat rectal prolapse. It involves fixing the rectum to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh. This procedure is performed via an abdominal approach and not through the perineum. Hence, the answer to the question is A) Ripstein operation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiersch operation: The Thiersch operation is a perineal procedure. It involves placing a wire or other synthetic material around the anus to encircle and narrow it. This provides support to the anal canal and rectum, helping to prevent or treat rectal prolapse.

 

Option C. Altemeier procedure: Also known as the perineal rectal resection, the Altemeier procedure is a surgical treatment for rectal prolapse. During this operation, the prolapsed portion of the rectum is resected, and the remaining rectum is sutured back to the anal canal. This procedure is performed through the perineal approach.

 

Option D. Delorme operation: The Delorme operation is a perineal approach to treat rectal prolapse. The mucosa and submucosa of the prolapsed rectum are excised, and the muscularis is plicated. The remaining mucosa is then sutured back. This procedure is typically reserved for older patients or those who are not candidates for a more invasive abdominal procedure.

choices.text: 2-10 mcg/kg/min
< 2 mcg/kg/min
10-20 mcg/kg/min

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta 1 receptors is:(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-10 mcg/kg/min

 

2-10 mcg/kg/min is the correct dose range at which dopamine primarily acts on beta 1 receptors in the heart, enhancing cardiac output by increasing heart rate and contractility.

 

Dopamine acts upon 3 receptors depending upon the dose:

 

D1 – < 2 mcg/kg/min (Present in the blood vessels of the kidney in highest concentration - Vasodilation and increased renal blood flow)

 

β1 – 2-10 mcg/kg/min (Present in the heart - Increased heart rate and contractility, which improves cardiac output)

 

α1 – >10 mcg/kg/min (Present in blood vessels - Vasoconstriction, which increases blood pressure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 2 mcg/kg/min: At this dose, dopamine primarily acts on D1 receptors, causing vasodilation and increased renal blood flow without significant effects on the heart.

 

Option C. 10-20 mcg/kg/min: At this higher dose, dopamine acts predominantly on alpha 1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. > 20 mcg/kg/min: Similar to the previous option, at doses higher than 20 mcg/kg/min, dopamine continues to exert effects primarily on alpha 1 receptors, resulting in significant vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine has dose-dependent receptor selectivity. It acts on beta 1 receptors at doses of 2-10 mcg/kg/min, increasing cardiac output by enhancing heart rate and contractility.

choices.text: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He has chest trauma, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. The patient is conscious but only able to speak in short phrases. On examination, there is hyperresonance on the affected side of the chest. What should be your next immediate step in managing this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

 

The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and hyper-resonance on the affected side is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

The next immediate step of management is inserting a needle i.e. needle decompression in the appropriate intercostal space (ICS).

 

The presence of hyper-resonance on percussion and the patient's signs of respiratory distress suggest a potential tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and compresses the lung, leading to severe respiratory compromise. Inserting a needle (needle decompression) in the appropriate intercostal space is a life-saving procedure to release the trapped air and relieve the pressure on the affected lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate: While maintaining a patient's airway is crucial in cases of respiratory distress, intubation is not the immediate next step in this case. The patient is conscious and speaking, indicating that they have a patent airway. The primary concern is addressing the chest trauma and potential tension pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Start intravenous fluids urgently: While providing intravenous fluids may be necessary, it is not the immediate priority in this case.

 

Option D. Take a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable diagnostic information, it is not the immediate next step in a suspected tension pneumothorax. Clinical signs and symptoms, including chest percussion and the patient's condition, warrant immediate intervention to relieve the pressure on the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of tension pneumothorax:

 

  • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line
  • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety
  • Note: According to ATLS 10th edition
  • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • However, In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe dehydration following two days of persistent vomiting and diarrhea. She appears lethargic, with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. The physician orders urgent fluid resuscitation, and the nurse selects the IV cannula shown in the image for insertion. What is the gauge size of the cannula displayed in the image, and what is its flow rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20G - 67 mL/min

 

Explanation:

 

The IV cannula displayed in the image is a 20-gauge (20G) cannula, identified by its pink color. The flow rate of a 20G cannula is approximately 67 mL/min, making it suitable for most routine intravenous infusions, including moderate fluid resuscitation, medication administration, and blood transfusions. The 20G cannula strikes a balance between sufficient flow rate and ease of insertion, making it a commonly chosen size in both emergency and routine settings.

 

Mnemonic for Remembering Sizes: "Very Young Boys Protect Girls with Grey Eyes"

 

  • V: Violet (26G)
  • Y: Yellow (24G)
  • B: Blue (22G)
  • P: Pink (20G)
  • G: Green (18G)
  • W: White (17G)
  • G: Grey (16G)
  • O: Orange (14G)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 18G - 103 mL/min: This option is incorrect because the 18G cannula is green and has a higher flow rate than the 20G, used for rapid fluid and blood administration.

 

Option C. 22G - 42 mL/min: This option is incorrect because the 22G cannula is blue, used primarily for slower infusions or smaller veins, with a lower flow rate.

 

Option D. 24G - 20 mL/min: This option is incorrect because the 24G cannula is yellow, primarily used for pediatric patients or those with very fragile veins, with the slowest flow rate among these options.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

 

  • A child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given X-ray suggest a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.
  • Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck X-rays were taken, and the flat surface of the coin in the esophagus is seen on the AP view, while the edge is seen on the lateral view.
  • Initial symptoms of esophageal foreign body ingestion include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea may also be seen.
  • Correct. If an object gets lodged in the esophagus, it can cause difficulty swallowing, pain, and drooling. The scenario presented indicates an X-ray showing a radiopaque foreign body (likely a coin or disc battery) in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body in the trachea: When a foreign body is stuck in the trachea, it is a life-threatening situation as it can block airflow. Symptoms would typically include coughing, choking, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. The flat surface would be better seen in the lateral view.

 

Option C. Artifact: An artifact in radiology refers to any distortion or error in the image that is not present in the patient. Artifacts can be due to the equipment, the patient's movement, or other factors.

 

Option D. Soft tissue calcification in the neck: This refers to the presence of calcified deposits in the soft tissues of the neck. These can be due to various reasons, such as long-standing inflammation, tumors, or other diseases. However, the presentation of acute difficulty in swallowing and the X-ray findings make this option unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  •  Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: What is the optimal urine output for a patient who has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour

 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is anticipated that the patient will have a normal urine output during the postoperative phase, which is 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour.

 

If converted into ml/day, approximately 1500 ml/day in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/minute, approximately 1 to 1.5 ml/minute in an avg. adult

 

If converted into ml/kg, approximately 12-36 ml/day in an avg. adult

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: A patient undergoes thyroid surgery, and their surgeon is aiming to minimize nerve injury during the procedure. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marginal mandibular nerve

 

The marginal mandibular nerve is located in the lower part of the face, near the mandible. It is not directly associated with thyroid surgery and is far less likely to be injured during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is one of the most critical nerves to be cautious of during thyroid surgery. It runs near or through the thyroid gland and is vulnerable to injury in region of Berry’s ligament.

 

Option B. Ansa cervicalis: The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by cervical spinal nerves. While it may be in the vicinity of thyroid surgery, it is less likely to be directly affected by the procedure compared to other nearby nerves like the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: The external laryngeal nerve is also in the vicinity of thyroid surgery and is most commonly injured during thyroid surgery. Its main function is to supply the cricothyroid muscle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The marginal mandibular nerve is the nerve least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.
  • The nerve is high up, closer to the mandibular margin.
  • The ansa cervicalis may be injured if the strap muscles are not cut high enough during surgery.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below the cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command - 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

choices.text: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically

 

Zone 2 hematoma is seen in flank region and typically related to renal injury. Zone 2 hematomas may be conserved unless they are expanding, when surgery is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively: Zone 1 hematoma refers to central zone, where likely structures injured are abdominal aorta or IVC are injured. Since these are major vascular injuries, all zone 1 hematomas should be explored.

 

Option B. Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored: Zone 3 refers to the pelvis region, and injuries in this area Should be managed conservatively with pelvic binder or external fixator. Exploration in these areas is dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible.

 

Option D. Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta: The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used during emergency laparotomies to visualize the abdominal aorta. It involves mobilizing the left sided abdominal viscera medially, which allows for better visualization of the retroperitoneum and the aorta. This maneuver can be useful in cases of trauma or other emergency situations where visualization of the aorta is necessary.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

 

Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is not a component of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad includes: jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, altered sensorium, and hypotension. Hematemesis can be a symptom of various other gastrointestinal issues but is not typically associated with cholangitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  2. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  3. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  4. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  5. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  6. Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen marked 2 in the image below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is the superior orbital fissure and the oculomotor nerve passes through this fissure.

 

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring. The oculomotor nerve passes through its intermediate compartment.

 

 

The oculomotor nerve primarily controls the movements of several eye muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (lifts the upper eyelid), and the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, which control eye movements. It also controls the constriction of the pupil (miosis) and accommodation of the lens for near vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Olfactory Nerve (CN I):

 

  • The olfactory nerve originates from the olfactory bulbs, which are extensions of the brain, located on the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone within the anterior cranial fossa.

 

  • The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell. It carries sensory information related to odors from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

Option C. Optic Nerve (CN II):

 

  • The optic nerve emerges from the optic canal, which is located in the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone within the middle cranial fossa.

 

  • The optic nerve is crucial for vision. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual stimuli.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • The facial nerve emerge from a stylomastoid foramen from the base of the skull.

 

  • It controls the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the production of saliva and tears. It also carries sensory information related to taste.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson 

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson Incision: This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle Incision: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher Incision: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

Most common type of PNET seen is: Insulinoma

 

Insulinomas are the most common type of PNETs. They produce excess insulin, leading to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) in affected individuals. Insulinomas are typically benign and occur more frequently than other types of PNETs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma: Gastrinoma is a type of PNET that produces excess gastrin hormone. It is associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are relatively less common than insulinomas.

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare PNETs that produce excess somatostatin hormone. They can occur in the pancreas or other parts of the digestive system. They are less common than insulinomas.
